For businesses that rely on complex supplier networks and face unpredictable market dynamics, resilience canâ€™t be an afterthought, it must be designed into the supply chain itself.

Thatâ€™s where supply chain orchestration comes in. Rather than focusing on isolated improvements within functional areas, orchestration integrates processes, data, and decision-making across the entire value chain. With the right strategy, companies can transform supply chains from reactive networks into connected ecosystems that anticipate shifts, adapt rapidly to disruptions, and deliver on customer promises.

To help you explore how orchestration creates more effective and future-ready supply chains, SAP, HP, and Accenture are hosting a  webinar designed for supply chain and operations leaders.

entry.title: Prevent an SAP Fiori / SAPUI5 Downtime â€” Check Your Browser Strategy Today!
entry.content:
This blog post was prompted by a recent issue in SAP customer support for SAP Fiori apps. I want to share the background, hoping it helps prevent a similar situation in your environment.


SAP Browser and Platform Support

SAP's Product Availability Matrix (PAM) provides the single source of truth for SAP software releases, including platform availability on browsers and operating systems. Regarding SAPUI5, note that SAPUI5 is not a product of its own, so please check the PAM for the product you're using SAPUI5 with. For more information, see SAP Note 1716423.

Browsers constantly evolve across devices to offer new capabilities and address newly detected security issues. Upgrades of browsers may introduce changes that are not backward compatible, affecting SAPUI5 and SAP software behavior. Browser upgrades may also require specific platform or operating system versions for all end users. Vendors do not provide (security) updates for browsers or platforms that are out of maintenance, which then are severe risk to productive environments. Keep in mind that SAP has no control over browser upgrades, their capabilities, or maintenance duration.

In other words: In Web development, especially with browsers: "Never touch a running system" is *NOT* an option.


Browsers for SAPUI5

SAPUI5 applications in productive SAP products require a minimum browser version to ensure full availability and security. This also lets SAPUI5 use current industry standards, such as ECMAScript, to deliver a modern and intuitive experience for SAP Business Suite.


Based on my own experience in the SAPUI5 team, I can confirm missing this requirement is a real-life risk. My conversations with customer support colleagues confirm this: productive SAP customers experienced outages because end users worked with browsers that were out of maintenance. One example can be seen in SAP Note 3639059 - Blank home screen in SAP Fiori Launchpad - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, which prompted this blog post. Using an outdated browser, end users saw a blank screen; developers got an error "Promise.withResolvers is not a function" in the console. The resolution for such cases is to update to the latest browser version, which in some cases may even require a costly operating system upgrade for all business users.

Therefore, I recommend monitoring the SAP Product Availability Matrix (PAM) and specifically the SAPUI5 Browser and Platform Support.

entry.title: SAP Field Logistics: Next Generation Kitting & Staging for MRO Industries
entry.content:
For any MRO organization (Maintenance, Repair, and Operations), kitting and staging is a core warehouse activity. On the surface, it seems simple. But in reality, it's a web of complexity, often managed by years of accumulated custom code and custom business process. 

Introducing Standard Kitting & Staging in S/4HANA 2023

With the release of S/4HANA 2023 FPS02, the struggle with custom kitting solutions is over. SAP has delivered a standard, industry-focused solution designed specifically for the intricacies of MRO: End-to-End Kitting & Staging with SAP Field Logistics.

This solution was co-designed with customers to address the real-world challenges you face every day. Itâ€™s built on six core principles to deliver a unified, streamlined process.

1. Centralize Kitting for Remote Operations Efficiently to build, stage, and dispatch kits from a central warehouse directly to remote or field locations, ensuring the right parts are in the right place at the right time.

2. Handle All Types of Goods Seamlessly Support not only inventory managed materials, but also non inventory stock, rental equipment and supplier provided items as part of services, ensuring full visibility and control across all goods movements

3. Empower Your Field Locations Donâ€™t just ship partsâ€”ship capability. Remote sites can now receive kits, manage kits, add locally held components, and issue the completed kit directly to a maintenance order.

4. Simplify and Standardize Your Processes Whether you operate a single, streamlined plant or manage a complex network of remote locations supported by a supply base, this solution provides a standard, repeatable process to eliminate guesswork and create one version of the truth for your kitting and staging operations.

5. Gain End-to-End Visibility in a Single Place Stop chasing information across different systems. The entire kitting lifecycleâ€”from creation and staging to dispatch and final issuanceâ€”is tracked in a single, accessible repository, giving you unprecedented control and insight. 

6. Scale for Your Environment This isn't a rigid, one-size-fits-all tool. The solution is designed to scale and adapt, supporting various warehouse management setups including Inventory Management (IM), Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), and even hybrid combinations depending on your organisation.

A Future-Proof Foundation for Your MRO Warehouse

By embedding this critical MRO process directly into the S/4HANA core, SAP has delivered a solution that is robust, scalable, and future proof. You can finally retire that aging custom code, move forward with confidence using a standard SAP solution at the base.

This is more than just a new feature; it's a new foundation for operational excellence in your MRO supply chain.

From Order to Staged Kit: A Look at the New Process

So, how does it actually work? The entire process is designed to be intuitive and integrated with maintenance and project business process.  And it all begins exactly where it should: with the demand from the field. 

Step 1: The Kit is Born from the Demand Signal It all starts with a Work Order or Network Order; the kit is automatically created and updated. As the requested materials arrive at the Supply Base, using the Field Logistics Cross-Docking process, the system automatically triggers the tracking milestones and begins the process of bringing everything together.

What truly sets this solution apart is its flexibility in defining the kit. You are no longer locked into a single method like in the past. At the demand plant level, you can define a kit based:

  • The Work Order/Network Order Header: Perfect for bundling all materials where work is planned and scheduled at the header.
  • A Work Order/Network Order Operation: Ideal for creating kits for specific phases or tasks within a more detailed planning and scheduling environment. 
  • A flexible definition via BAdI: For unique business requirements, this allows you to implement custom logic while remaining within the standard framework.

Step 2: Augment the Kit with Local Inventory The process doesn't stop with the initial cross dock. If required, you can easily supplement the base kit by adding stock directly from local base inventory or as more cross docking occurs. This hybrid approach allows you to combine centrally sourced materials with locally available parts for maximum efficiency, speed and tracking.

Step 3: Pack, Stage, and Track with Precision Once complete, the kit can be packed into standard Field Logistics objects like Containers or Packages.

Crucially, every objectâ€”including the delivery items â€”can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field via the Pack Containers (F5786)app. This eliminates guesswork and "lost" kits. The result is pinpoint accuracy on the warehouse floor, where everyone knows exactly what a kit contains, where it is, and which job itâ€™s for.

Flexibility at the Edge: Managing Kits Upon Arrival

The journey doesn't end when the kit leaves the central warehouse. A core strength of SAP Field Logistics is its ability to track the Supply Chain end to end. The solution is designed to handle several common scenarios:

Scenario 1: The "Base Kit" Handover

In this model, all components have been kitted at the central base. The kit arrives at the remote location fully prepared. The process here is built for speed and simplicity:

  • Receive: The remote site performs a simple goods receipt for the complete kit.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 2: The "Remote Kit" Assembly

This scenario is common in industries like Mining or Land-Based Operations where remote sites are highly self-sufficient. Here, no physical goods are shipped from the base. Instead:

  • Demand Signal: The demand is to be supplied fully from the remote site.
  • Local Assembly: The kit is assembled and managed entirely at the remote location using its locally held inventory. This empowers the remote team to take full ownership of the kitting process and support the operations stocking strategy.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 3: The "Re-Kit" Hybrid Model

This flexible, hybrid approach offers the best of both worlds. A base kit containing centrally sourced or specialized parts is shipped from the main warehouse. Upon arrival:

  • Receive Base Kit: The initial kit is received at the remote location.
  • Augment Locally: The remote team then adds further components to the kit directly from their local inventory to create the final package.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

This adaptabilityâ€”from a simple handover to full remote assemblyâ€”ensures that no matter your operational model, the system supports your reality on the ground.

Mastering "The Last Mile": Detailed Tracking at the Remote Site

The final journey of a kitâ€”from the remote warehouse shelf to the hands of a technicianâ€”is often a logistical black box. This critical phase, aptly named "The Last Mile," is where parts get misplaced, jobs get delayed, and efficiency breaks down. A common problem is the lack of real-time visibility once a kit is "in the system" but not yet in use.

SAP Field Logistics solves this by introducing key tracking milestones for the entire "Last Mile" lifecycle. Now, users can pinpoint exactly where everything is in real-time.

1. Stage - Once a kit item is received or assembled at the remote location, its status is set to Staged. It is officially logged as staged and ready for the job. The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin using a dedicated standard field. The warehouse knows exactly what is ready and precisely where to find it.

2. Drop - As the job start time approaches, the kit needs to move closer to the point of work. When this happens, its status is updated to Dropped. It can then be assigned to a nominated drop pointâ€”like a specific laydown yard or workshop areaâ€”again using a dedicated standard location field.

3. Issue - This is the final, crucial handover. The kits items status is updated to Issued at the moment the technician formally receives the complete kit. This closes the loop on the logistics process, providing a clear and simple audit trail. It confirms that the right parts were delivered to the right person at the right time, minimizing disputes and ensuring the job can begin without delay.

Unlocking Total Visibility: Answering "Where Is My Stuff?"

In any MRO operation, the question "Where is my stuff?" is asked daily. But "stuff" can mean anythingâ€”an individual component, a complex kit for a shutdown, or all the materials for a week's worth of routine maintenance. Answering this question accurately and in real-time has always been a major challenge.

SAP Field Logistics answers this question by tracking every item against extensive, standard milestones, it provides a single source of truth. This critical information is no longer buried in spreadsheets or system tables; it is visualized in intuitive Fiori applications and via exposed API's.

While day-to-day operations are handled in the Manage Kits (F8005) and Manage Logistics (F5082) apps, the consolidated view of this new visibility comes to life in the Logistics Tracking (F7382) app.

First delivered with S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, the Logistics Tracking App has now been specifically enhanced to include the key kitting milestones. This means the "Last Mile" statusesâ€”Stage, Drop, and Issueâ€”are now surfaced directly in this central dashboard.

The result is a single view where planners, supervisors, and technicians can see the real-time status of any component or kit, from the central warehouse all the way to the point of use. The question is no longer "Where is my stuff?" but "What do I need to look at next?"

Five Core Capabilities That Transform MRO Logistics

Having walked through the end-to-end process, from the central warehouse to the final handover, we can see how SAP Field Logistics delivers a set of transformative capabilities that directly address the core challenges of MRO supply chains.

1. A Single, Standardized Process from Warehouse to Worksite For the first time, a single, standard process governs the entire kitting lifecycle. From the initial build in a supply base to augmenting a kit at a remote site and issuing it to a technician, the system provides one unified framework. This eliminates process variations, reduces training overhead, and establishes a foundation for operational excellence across the entire organization.

2. Real-Time, End-to-End Visibility The question "Where is my stuff?" is definitively answered. Through the Logistics Tracking App and dedicated Fiori dashboards, you have a single source of truth. By tracking key milestones like Staged, Dropped, and Issued, you gain complete, real-time visibility into the "Last Mile," enabling better decision-making and proactive control.

3. Flexibility for Real-World Operations This is not a rigid, one-size-fits-all solution. It is built to adapt to your reality. Whether you need to define a kit by an entire work order or a specific operation, or whether you manage kits centrally, remotely, or through a hybrid model, the solution provides the flexibility to support your specific business needs.  For example - your operation does not drop but issues directly from staging, this is supported.

4. Integration with Core Maintenance and Warehouse Processes SAP Field Logistics is not a standalone module; it is woven into the digital core. It integrates seamlessly with Maintenance Orders, Network Orders, Logistics Execution (LE), Inventory Management (IM), and Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). This ensures data consistency, prevents information silos, and creates a smooth, automated flow from maintenance planning to field execution.

5. Finally Retire Custom Code and Embrace a Clean Core Perhaps the most strategic benefit is the ability to finally retire your expensive, high-risk custom kitting solutions. By moving this critical functionality into the S/4HANA standard, you can eliminate technical debt, simplify future upgrades, and fully embrace a "clean core" strategy. This reduces your total cost of ownership and positions your organization on a future-proof platform for years to come.

Conclusion: The Future is Standard

For years, managing MRO kitting has meant a compromise. Organizations were forced to choose between a standard SAP process that didn't fully meet their needs or investing heavily in complex, custom-coded solutions that created technical debt and upgrade risk. These "Z-solutions," while functional, were brittle, expensive to maintain, and operated in a silo with each customer to define everything including integration.

With the introduction of SAP Field Logistics in S/4HANA, that era is over.

The journey from a fragmented, high-maintenance custom process to a powerful, flexible, and standard solution is no longer a future ambitionâ€”it is a present reality. We have seen how Field Logistics provides a single, unified framework to:

  • Define and build kits with flexibility.
  • Manage them across diverse remote site scenarios.
  • Track them through "The Last Mile."
  • Visualize their status in real-time for all stakeholders.

This is more than a new module; it is a fundamental shift in strategy. It is the opportunity to finally retire your custom code, shed decades of technical debt, and embrace a "clean core" architecture. It's a chance to align your operations with a future-proof platform that will evolve with your business, not hold it back.

The path forward is no longer about building a better workaround; it's about leveraging a better standard. The future of MRO logistics isn't custom; it's standard and powered by Field Logistics.

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About the SAP Young Professionals Program
entry.content:
If youâ€™re an ambitious graduate looking to launch your tech consulting career, the SAP Young Professionals program might be the opportunity youâ€™ve been waiting for! This free, immersive training experience opens doors to become an SAP Associate Consultant and kick-start your career among SAP's. 

What is the SAP Young Professionals program?

It is a free, 2-3 month intensive training initiative from the SAP Digital Skills Center that aims to equip recent university graduates (with less than 3 years of graduation) with SAP knowledge, soft skills, and certifications that prepare them for SAP consulting-related position within the EMEA region. 

Graduates are trained in SAP technologies such as: SAP S/4HANA , SAP Analytics Cloud ,  Artificial Intelligence , SAP Business Technology Platform , within others ((Modules may vary by cohort or region).

Who is eligible for the program?

Applicants typically need to meet the following criteria.

  • Hold a university degree (Bachelorâ€™s or higher). 
  • Be a recent graduate (within the past 3 years).
  • Be currently unemployed or underemployed
  • Show strong English proficiency.
  • Be citizens or legal residents of the country where the program is being offered.

Note: Specific requirements may vary depending on country and region.

What does the program include?

Over the course of 2â€“3 months, participants will:

  • Earn globally recognized certifications 
  • Gain access to SAP Learning Hub and be trained by SAP specialists 
  • Develop soft skills
  • Have the possibility of starting your career as Associate Consultant in SAP's ecosystem (partners + customers)

Is the program really free?

Yes. The SAP Digital Skills Center delivers this program at no cost to participants as part of SAPâ€™s mission to close the digital skills gap and support sustainable employment. SAP invests in rising talent to help drive digital transformation across industries.

Is employment guaranteed after completing the program?

While job placement is not guaranteed, one of the key goals of YPP is to connect graduates with SAP partners and customers who are actively hiring. Many graduates secure employment within the SAP ecosystem shortly after completing the program. However, success depends on the graduate's performance, certification results, and engagement throughout the course.

How to apply?

Applications are submitted via ðŸ‘‰  SAP Digital Skills Center portal.

Keep an eye on the website or SAPâ€™s social media channels for announcements about new program cohorts in your region.

entry.title: The Smart Path to S/4HANA EWM
entry.content:
Overview of the current four solutions

There are currently four SAP solutions to help you manage your warehouse: Stockroom Management; Warehouse Management; EWM Basic; and EWM Advanced. Below, weâ€™ll look at the differences between them. Note that there will be no further development of the first two, as SAP is positioning EWM on S/4HANA as the strategic choice going forward. Its key benefits include:

  • Better warehouse performance
  • Complete process and stock transparency
  • Preconfigured best practice content
  • Clear roadmap of future developments
  • Supported by latest technologies and continuous innovation
  • Scalability and flexible extension options
  • Lowest TCO

Can Stockroom Management replace a transition to EWM?

You probably know that SAP introduced SAP Stockroom Management in 2020, running on S/4HANA. This solution is helpful for small warehouses with predominantly manual processes that only require a few basic functions, such as storage bin management. However, it isnâ€™t suited to industrial companies looking to streamline their logistical processes across the board. For example, Stockroom Management doesnâ€™t include functions such as task and resource management; value-added services; cross-docking; picking waves; or WM-LSR. As noted above, this product will not be developed any further.

Choosing the right EWM solution for you

Now that weâ€™ve established that most companies will likely want to transition to EWM, letâ€™s look at the options available. In terms of the solutions embedded in S/4HANA, you can choose between EWM Basic Warehousing and EWM Advanced Warehousing, for which an additional license is required.  If you prefer a decentralized solution, SAP offers the extended cloud variant of EWM as well as the decentralized version on S/4HANA. Itâ€™s important for companies to look into the features and functions they need for their processes and what could be dropped. Hereâ€™s an overview to make your selection easier.

 

 

Overview of features and functions in SAP WM offerings

SDT: the optimal migration approach for EWM

Unlike an ECC to S/4HANA transition, migrating to EWM is a little more complex in that the previous system was part of SCM as opposed to ECC. As such, a classic brownfield migration using automatic system conversion isnâ€™t available. One solution would be to start from scratch with a new system (greenfield), although this involves redesigning your processes. Selective data transformation is clearly the better option here, as it enables you to reuse your business and historical data while updating your existing processes. This migration concept is available from SAP as well as its SDT partners: Natuvion, cbs, and SNP.  These offer specialized migration and mapping tools that accelerate the process of data analysis, selection, and verification.

The importance of dealing with transactional data

Customers using EWM 9.x can use the SAP Migration Cockpit to move to S/4HANA, although the cockpit doesnâ€™t handle transactional data, cross-client customizing or user authentication so companies would need to look after those aspects themselves or work with their SAP SDT partner. If they are unable to leave the old transactional data behind, they could use SAPâ€™s SDT partnersâ€™ tools to transfer it to the central control system, then to map and update the transactional data prior to migrating it to the new EWM system.

Deciding what to migrate and what to archive

Many companies find the process complex as they often use highly specialized processes, making it difficult to decide what to transfer and what to leave behind. In addition, there may be legal considerations such as a requirement to retain data for a certain number of years. SAP and its SDT partners can assist with this process, particularly with regard to reducing the size of the database to be migrated. S/4HANA databases can be expensive to maintain if they are large and continue to grow. Archiving solutions are available that enable you to keep and access the old data for auditing and research purposes, while only transferring currently useful data. This approach offers big benefits in terms of cost and performance for the new system while preserving and protecting the historical data.

Three key aspects to consider before starting an EWM migration

 

  • The first elementto consider is dealing with the custom code â€“ repository objects â€“ as many warehouses have very specific hardware and structures. The Custom Code Impact Analysis service can help here, as it highlights whether and how this data will be affected by the move to the new infrastructure.
  • The second aspectis closing the old documents. A prerequisite of S/4HANA is that docs are closed before being moved. Yet some documents canâ€™t be closed, especially quality inspection documents and others that have to be open all the time. The SDT approach helps here as it will move both open and closed documents. This applies whether youâ€™re choosing the embedded or the decentralized SAP EWM solution.
  • Last but not least, downtime.Greenfield projects require several shorter downtime incidences, while SDT usually only requires one. Near-zero downtime may not be possible given the specificities of warehouse systems, but the right tools, like those offered by the SAP SDT partners can make a significant contribution to reducing the impact on business continuity.

 

Decentralized option for better performance

SAP and its SDT partners have estimated that 90-95% of their customers decide on a decentralized EWM system on S/4HANA in preference to the embedded variant. This is because itâ€™s the strategic platform and more future-proof from a data volume perspective, especially for customers with large databases and warehouse systems.  In addition, if someone else in your company is doing some heavy-duty data extraction on the ERP system, there may be a slowdown effect on an EWM embedded in the ERP system that would not arise with a decentralized option.

Talk to us!

Despite the complexities of moving from an SCM-based solution to EWM on S/4HANA, SAP and its SDT partners have the tools and experience to smooth the path for its customers. Feel free to contact us to find out more.

For further information you can also have a look into our webinar "SDT - how to deal with other SAP suite solutions? Focus: EWM".

entry.title: Service Entry Sheet Accruals - Posting and Configurations for SAP S/4HANA 2023
entry.content:
1.  Overview

In SAP S/4HANA, a Service Entry Sheet (SES) is used to confirm that services ordered through a purchase order have been rendered by the vendor. Once accepted, the SES triggers the posting of a service receipt in the system, which serves as the basis for vendor invoicing and financial postings.

Accruals in the context of SES ensure that expenses for services received but not yet invoiced are recognized in the correct accounting period. This is critical for accurate period-end closing, aligning with accrual-based accounting principles. In SAP S/4HANA, the system can automatically generate accrual postings for unbilled services, recording them in GR/IR (Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt) or specific accrual accounts, depending on configuration.

The process typically involves:

  1. Creation of Purchase Order (PO) for services.
  2. Entry of Service Entry Sheet and Send for Approval
  3. Automatic Posting for Accrual at period-end for unapproved SES items.

With the Service Entry Sheet Accrual, organizations benefit from:

entry.title: Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results
entry.content:
Summary

This blog post describes how to build a planning monitoring tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials. This tool can show per material the historical consumption data â€“ consumption-based planning â€“ together with the stocks and requirements information â€“ material requirements planning â€“, and the corresponding MRP created receipt elements to cover the shortages.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on the visualization of the MRP results.

 

Introduction

A typical customer requirement is to visualize the result of the MRP run for several materials in a report format, that is, they want MD04 for every material on a plant in a single screen. The purpose is to have an easy and fast way of identification of critical materials where the planner needs to take an action, and then being able to select the specific material and drill down into the stock, requirements and planning elements details. There is not a standard report available that would show a detailed display of stock/requirements list for multiple materials.

A collective MRP results view is normally something very difficult to build, as companies have thousands of materials per plant with different business cases concerning procurement types, planning strategies, production types, origin of the requirements, etcâ€¦ Furthermore, the target information to be displayed is different depending on the user role:

  • As a production supervisor, buyer, sales executive or MRP controller, you want to access information on the stock/requirements situation of the material, and then gain an overview of the development of stock and requirements in the coming weeks.
  • As a production supervisor, you want to gain an overview of the MRP elements for in-house production (planned orders, production orders, dependent reservations) or of the MRP elements for a particular production line.
  • As a buyer, you want to check which purchase orders and purchase requisitions exist for a material for a particular vendor.
  • As a sales executive, you are only interested in the current sales orders for a particular customer for a material.
  • As an MRP controller, you are interested in available quantities based on sales orders that have actually been received and not on the basis of the planned independent requirements. You therefore want the planned independent requirements to be displayed, but do not want to change the available quantity if sales order exists.
  • As an MRP controller, you want to be informed about the requirements of bulk materials or materials that are planned using consumption-based planning, to check whether these requirements occur continually.

Another issue to consider is the requirement of some customers to manage historical consumption data together with the requirements information, thus allowing them to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same periods in the same single screen.

Therefore, having all these requirements and conditions in mind, we may think that building a collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials becomes a great challenge. This blog explains how this collective planning tool can be built for isolated and specific planning scenarios.

 

Evaluating the Planning Run on SAP S/4HANA

For Classic MRP, the available tools for checking the planning results are the following:

  • Stock/Requirements List
  • MRP List
  • Evaluation of the Planning Situation
  • Evaluation of the Planning Result
  • Planning Table for repetitive manufacturing

During the planning run, the system analyzes the requirements that exist for the planned materials and creates procurement or manufacturing elements to cover these requirements. The evaluations on these tools show all receipt and issue elements for a material in tabular form and enable you to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements situation for the material as well as to branch into the processing function for the MRP elements for this material.

In the stock/requirements list, the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation is displayed. Changes that are made after the planning date are displayed directly, so the list is dynamic. The MRP list always displays the stock/requirements situation at the time of the last planning run. Changes that are made after the planning date are not taken into consideration, so the list is static.

The planning situation takes all changes in stock, receipts and issues that occur between planning runs into account (as in the stock/requirements list). The planning result displays the result of the last planning run (as in the MRP list). The main difference is that you set up a special evaluation layout for the formatting of the data in the planning result and planning situation. This layout defines which receipt and issue elements are displayed at which level of aggregation.

In SAP S/4HANA, the MRP Live is used, and we also have the MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps and the MPR Situation Handling. MRP Lists are gone with MRP Live due to the considerable performance improvement. The several available MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps display an overview of materials with possible stock shortages, and you can also drill down into a specific material to see the stock/requirements situation.

The new Fiori Apps for MRP evaluation are more visually appealing, and they contain features only available in Fiori, such as Demand-Driven MRP (DDMRP) and Predictive MRP (pMRP). Moreover, they are also supported in mobile devices.

On below table you can find a summary of the abovementioned MRP transactions or Fiori Apps:

Application

Description

Transaction MD04        

Display Individual Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD07

Display Collective Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD05

Individual Display of MRP List

Transaction MD06

Collective Display of MRP List

Transaction MD44

Planning Situation

Transaction MD47

Collective Display for Planning Situation

Transaction MD45

Planning Result

Transaction MD46

Collective Display for Planning Result

Transaction MD48

Multi-Plant Planning Situation

Fiori App F0251A

Manage Material Coverage

Fiori App F2101A

Monitor Material Coverage

 

Customer Requirement for a Collective Evaluation of the MRP Planning Results

Customer business case was a small-sized food company with mainly a mass production environment using discrete manufacturing. Main finished products were fresh products sent to retailers to be sold on the supermarketâ€™s shelf. Therefore, demand was seasonal but also with a special focus on daily consumption pattern.  The customer was interested on running the MRP with requirements based on forecast demand, but also considering the historical consumption of the last four weeks per day, to have the whole picture.

Since it was just a small company, there were only two main MRP responsible for the whole of the planning process and availability control for purchasing products, intermediate production and final product production. The two main areas of responsibility were MPS products, covering the final products to sale, and MRP products, covering the products for purchasing and intermediate production. On this blog we will focus on the MRP products.

The customer used a make-to-stock production (goods sold from stock) because of the following reasons:

  • The materials were produced independently of the sales orders.
  • The materials were not assigned to specific sales orders (not segregated).
  • Costs was required to be tracked at material level, and not at sales order level.

The main objective was to quickly provide the clients with goods from the stock. The main constraint was that real sales orders were often received from clients only for one day, and normally with just one day in advance or even the same day. Therefore, customer needed to produce goods without having the sales orders, as expecting the clients demand in future.

On this make-to-stock scenario, to avoid unreasonably high stock levels, a production plan is created in advance, and then you decide whether sales orders exceeding your plan are to affect production or not. Receiving sales orders as early as possible (using scheduling agreements, for example) also contributes to minimize high stock levels, but it was unrealistic on this customer, so a smooth demand forecast was key.

The production was determined by a production plan based on demand forecast (demand management), and only sales orders for first day exceeding the plan directly influenced production. If available, sales order information for subsequent days was required to be displayed for information purposes only (as normally info was uncompleted), but forecast was the demand driver except for the first day. Therefore, planning strategy used was net requirements planning on plant level (strategy 10), which allows to smooth the demand program.

Another very important considerations of the customer for achieving an effective materials planning were the following:

  • Customer wanted to expedite material planning with a more detailed collective material overview than the one provided by standard SAP S/4HANA MRP apps.
  • Customer requested to analyze materials on a dynamic periodic basis, mainly daily, but also weekly and monthly. The operative planning is usually managed by day, meanwhile medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.
  • Customer requested a calculation of stock coverage for every period displayed.
  • Customer worked with two planning modes: the real-time mode, like MD04 with the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation, and the fix-photo mode, similar to MD05 (MRP-List) with a snapshot at the beginning of the day with the situation of initial stock, requirements and receipts.
  • Customer did not plan materials at MRP areas level.
  • Customer needed a more flexible material selection by using the typical grouping fields available on material master.
  • Customer needed a flexible visualization of quantities in several units of measure.

Customer requirement for MRP monitoring was to build a new collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials. On this tool, future requirements would be displayed together with historical data, thus allowing the customer to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period. Initial stock and final stock situation for every period based on total requirements and receipts were also required to be displayed.

Final decision was to create two similar planning monitoring tools: one focused on MPS products, the MPS Production Planning Monitor, and other focused on MRP products, the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor. On this blog we will focus on the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor, which is described in detail down below.

Figure 1: Material Scope for MRP Live run with MPS/MRP materials.

 

Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

The Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP was intended for displaying the stock/requirements/receipts situation for a particular or a series of materials, from the point of view of purchasing or intermediate production. The prerequisite was the MRP Live (operative production plan MPS & MRP) previously executed for the corresponding plant, and this was automatically done daily at night by a background job.

The evaluations on this Monitor display all receipt and issue elements for the materials in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material, as well as to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements for this material. After a normal MPS&MRP run, the planner checks the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the materials, make necessary changes and ensures the availability of the materials for the next days, by creating purchase or production orders. The tool also allowed working by fixing the planning elements either purchase requisitions or planned orders, but customer planners used to directly create the purchase or production orders.

As planners of this customer were old-school heavy users of SAP systems, this Monitor was developed in form of ALV list by using the BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST function.

 

Selection Screen for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

The selection screen of the new Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool is displayed on below image (Figure 2):

Figure 2: Selection Screen of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool.

 

The period to be considered must be selected using the fields â€œDate Fromâ€ and â€œDate Toâ€. One week is proposed by default.

Requirements/receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field â€œPeriod Typeâ€. The operative planning (short-term planning) is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.

The materials to be shown can be selected by material type, material group, MRP controller and/or material code.

The default â€œPlanning Modeâ€ is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (â€œPlanning Fix-Photoâ€). Using this mode the entire requirements of the day and the entire purchase orders are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (â€œPlanning Real-Timeâ€). Using this other mode only the pending requirements of the day and the pending purchase orders are shown.

The quantities shown can be displayed on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user.

The total percentage of loss of the materials can be displayed as scrap (internal SAP), but also as drop or yield. This is just a percentage related to food processing to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The calculation of stock coverage on periods can be dynamically changed to consider or not the â€œ-Expired stockâ€ and the â€œ+Purchasesâ€.

Finally, consumption history can be shown together with MRP data, for 1 period only or for 4 periods.

 

Output List for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

An example of the output list of the new Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool is displayed on below image (Figure 3):

Figure 3: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool.

 

This new monitoring tool allows to display at the same time the following data:

  • MRP planning results over sales & forecast (future).
  • Consumption history (past).

The MRP evaluation on this Monitor displays all receipt and issue elements for every material in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material. Moreover, for every period the historical consumption for the material is shown for the fourth previous periods, and also the average. This allows the planner to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period.

Requirements are shown in negative - quantity and receipts in positive + quantity, in order to ease the coverage understanding. A colour code red-yellow-green is used on field â€œStock Finalâ€ to easily identify stock breaks.

This new tool also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell.

The explanation of the meaning of the different columns of the new Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool is summarized on below image (Figure 4):

Figure 4: Explanation of the Columns of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool.

 

Displaying Options for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

Requirements and receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field â€œPeriod Typeâ€ on the selection screen. The operative planning is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning is managed by week/month.

 

Figure 5: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool with Period Type by Week.

Figure 6: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool with Period Type by Month.

 

The monitor has an option for avoiding displaying empty lines, thus planner being able to only focus on periods containing data.

Figure 7: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool without empty lines.

 

The monitor also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell. The available screens for the data details are the following:

  • With double-click on the initial stock cell of the first period (current period), you navigate to detail stock list.
  • With double-click on any requirements cell, you navigate to detail requirements list.
  • With double-click on any receipts cell, you navigate to detail receipts list.
  • With double-click on any consumption cell, you navigate to detail historical consumption list.

Figure 8: Detail Stock List when double-clicking on the initial stock cell of the first period

Figure 9: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on any requirement cell

Figure 10: Detail Receipts List with Purchase Orders when double-clicking on any receipt cell (external procurement material)

Figure 11: Detail Receipts List with Production Orders when double-clicking on any receipt cell (internal procurement material)

Figure 12: Detail Historical Consumption List when double-clicking on any consumption cell 13

 

For dummy materials (non-stock managed, phantoms), the corresponding production requirements are also available on the monitor, both the totals and the detail list.

Figure 13: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool with requirements details

 

The monitor has two planning modes: the fix-photo mode and the real-time mode, similar to classic MRP List (static) and Stocks/Requirements List (dynamic). The default planning mode is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (â€œPlanning Fix-Photoâ€). Using this mode, the entire requirements of the day and the entire receipts (purchase and manufacturing) are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (â€œPlanning Real-Timeâ€). Using this other mode, only the pending requirements of the day and the pending purchase/manufacturing orders are shown.

Figure 14: Output List of the Monitor for the different Planning Modes.

Figure 15: Output List with Details for the different Planning Modes.

 

The monitor can display the quantities on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user. This can be done either on the selection screen or directly on the main screen, as well as the planning mode.

Figure 16: Output List of the Monitor showing quantities in different units of measure.

 

Finally, the Monitor can display the total percentage of loss of the materials as scrap, like standard SAP, but also as drop or yield. This is just a percentage related to food processing loss, but very relevant for the planner when taking purchase decisions during the evaluation process.

Figure 17: Output List of the Monitor showing total percentage of loss by different ways.

 

Action Buttons for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

The Monitor has an action button to create a new purchase order. Furthermore, on the different screens with the details list of receipts, when clicking on the purchase or production order, the monitor navigates to the corresponding maintenance application, where the user can directly edit the date and/or the quantity. This considerably improves the number of clicks required to perform those actions compared to use new modes.

 

Figure 18: Output List of the Monitor with the action button â€œCreate New Purchase Orderâ€.

entry.title: Simplifying Field Service with AI in SAP FSM
entry.content:
Introduction:

SAP field service management operations set up for any new company settings requires careful planning, which has become much easier with the help of built in cloud AI features. With the help of these smart tools companies in FSM helps with much better decision making. Which also helps the technicians to complete their work more efficiently since they will be getting real-time support, faster & for instance access to the information which they require and smart scheduling. This results in lesser delays, and much improved service quality.

 Prerequisites for SAP Cloud FSM:

  • Must have a valid license for SAP AI Units.
  • Premium AI features must be activated in FSM tenant.
  • Sufficient Historical Data (1000 activities with the execution Stage should be equal to CLOSE status in order to train the system)


Key AI Features in SAP FSM:

Below is the breakdown of the core AI functionalities available

1. Intelligent Filtering

  1. Assignment Duration Prediction
  2. Activity Summary
  3. Equipment Summary

 

-> Intelligent Filtering:

Intelligent Filtering will help by showing the most relevant technicians only for the job and automatically sorting. which is like having a smart assistant that understands the input. Instead of checking each customer manually system will sort them based on the requirements of the job, then you will be getting a list of customers who passed the requirements which leads to lesser time consumption and better accuracy.
For example, imagine you're a dispatcher in FSM who is trying to assign a technician to a service job, you have list of technicians, but not all of them are suitable for all tasks, some might be far away, some might not be having the right skills, and others might already busy with other service jobs assigned previously. so based on the below points we can perform the intelligent filtering.

  • What the job needs (Like skills, tools, etc.)
  • Which technicians are available to perform the service task
  • Who is nearby to perform the service task
  • Who has done the similar job well previously.

Why Itâ€™s Useful:

  • Lesser time consumption: No need to manually check the list of all customers.
  • Reduced errors: Selects only technicians who are qualified and are available.
  • Improved customer service: Faster and better matches which results in the quicker resolutions for the tasks.


Steps to Enable:

  1. Raise an Incident:
    • Go to your SAP support portal.
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI.
    • Mention that you have a valid license and want to activate Intelligent Filtering.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature:
    • Once the request is processed, SAP will activate the feature in your FSM environment.
  3. Verify in the FSM Portal:
    • Navigate to the Planning & Dispatching module.
    • Youâ€™ll see technician suggestions ranked intelligently when assigning service calls.

Compared to the older Best Matching Technician plugin, Intelligent Filtering is smarter and much easier to use. The old plugin works based on business rules which has been set up for every company, like checking technician skills or distance. whereas Intelligent Filtering in FSM uses the AI to understand what exactly dispatcher is looking for in the technicians and it automatically suggests the best technicians available for the service task.  It is much faster, that means it supports natural language searches. And it also gives the extra insights like past equipment history (which is not available in the old plugin doesnâ€™t offer).


-> Assignment Duration Prediction:

Assignment Duration Prediction can be seen during the dispatching of an activity which will provide the overview like how long it will take to complete the current service task, which technician will be suitable for this activity rather than dispatcher guessing how long it might take to complete the current service tasks.

It uses the data like below:

  • The type of service task which needs to be assigned
  • The technicianâ€™s past performance on the service tasks
  • Historical data which are similar to the current service task
  • Job priority and some other requirements

This will help the dispatchers to plan accurately and helps to avoid the delay.

 Why Itâ€™s Useful:

  •  Better scheduling: can avoid the overloading the technicians.
  • Lesser delays during the assignment of service tasks.

Steps to Enable:

  1. Training the (AI Model) system

You can do this in two easy ways:

  • Option A: Use the Settings Screen

  • Option B: Use a Sample Business Rule
    • Download the sample rule from SAP Help.

  1. Activate the Feature
  • Go to: Settings and Configuration â†’ Planning and Dispatching â†’ General Settings â†’ Activity Planning â†’ Additional Settings

    â€œAllow assignment duration prediction for semi and fully automated schedulingâ€
  1. Start Using It

-> Activity Summary:

Activity summary is like an assistant who give you the overview of the activity like what technician was doing, it gives you the summarized explanation of activity in detail, it helps the dispatcher to understand the below points:

  • what types of jobs were completed by technicians?
  • how much time did they take to complete the activity?

  3. Check in the FSM Portal
    • Go to the Planning and Dispatching module
    • Youâ€™ll see AI-generated summaries for completed jobs

 

-> Equipment Summary:

Equipment Summary is similar to activity summary where in the activity summary we will be getting the summary of the completed activity but in the equipment summary we will be getting the summary of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks. it provides the details of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks which will help the dispatcher to make better decisions like.

  • if there is any issue related to this equipment that can be seen in the equipment summary along with that, we can also see the performance of the equipment over time

Why Itâ€™s Useful:

  • it saves time by giving the summary of the equipment in an instance rather than going through the equipment history record
  • if there is any reoccurring issue that can be fixed with the help of this feature so it will be very useful for preventive maintenance activities


Steps to Enable:

    • Inside the service call, go to the General Information tab.

  4. Review and Use the Summary
    • The system will show a short, AI-generated summary of the equipmentâ€™s history.

 

 

Conclusion:

SAP FSMâ€™s AI features help the service teams to work much faster and smarter by reducing the manual effort and better decision making.

entry.title: Long running phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I in ECC to S/4 conversion using DMOVE to S/4 with Do-DMO
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, I will share the details of the issue, troubleshooting steps, and the solution that helped me resolve  the long running phase: PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I during conversion in SUM tool.

During a recent ECC to SAP S/4HANA 2023 conversion project using DMOVE to S/4 using DoDMO, we encountered a major performance bottleneck.
The SUM phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I, which typically should not take very long, ended up running for more than 30 hours without completing.

 

Background

  • Source system: ECC 6 EHP 8 on DB2 v11.5.9.0
  • Target system: S/4HANA 2023 FPS01
  • SUM version: SUM 2.0 SP23
  • Method: DMOVE to S/4 using DoDMO
  • OS version: SLES 15 SP05 (both Source and target)

The conversion was progressing smoothly until the phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I.

The Issue:

During the conversion, Software Update Manager (SUM) entered the phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I and it was running very slow.

This phase is part of the preparation import steps and is mainly responsible for:

  • Importing tool-related transport objects into the shadow system.
  • These objects are necessary for SUM to run subsequent phases.
  • It typically involves R3trans and tp calls that execute DDIC and tool transports.

Expected Behavior

  • Normally, this step should finish within a few min to hour (depending on system size and DB performance).

The logs (TOOLIMP_I.LOG) should show a sequence of transport requests being imported with steady progress.

 

How we Overcame the Issue

After confirming that the TOOLIMP_I phase was progressing extremely slowly with no obvious system bottleneck, I decided to take corrective action. Below are the exact steps that resolved the issue.

Terminate Processes

  • Killed all R3trans and tp put processes running on the Additional Application Server (AAS) where SUM was initiated.
  • Also killed the SAPup process on the AAS to terminate the running phase PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I.

Ensure DIR_PUT Consistency

  • The parameter DIR_PUT (checked in transaction RZ11) must be consistent between the Primary Application Server (PAS) and the AAS.

Example: DIR_PUT = /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap
In my case, SUM was started from a different mount point on AAS:
/Migration/SUM
To fix this, I created a soft link under /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM pointing to the /Migration/SUM directory.

Copy SUM Directory

  • Copied the entire SUM directory from the AAS to PAS on below location
    /usr/sap/<SID>/

Adjust TOOLIMPI.TPP

Edit the file: /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/var/TOOLIMPI.TPP on the PAS and make sure its points correctly to PAS folders and files. Below is the screenshot showing how the file was correctly edited on PAS.

What is TOOLIMPI.TPP?

  • This is the tp parameter profile for the TOOLIMP_I phase.
  • It tells the tp tool how to perform the transport import.
  • SUM generates this dynamically for each import phase.
  • Key things it controls include: transport directory paths, buffer handling, import options, trace level, and return codes.

Clean Up Old TMP Files

  • Navigate to /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/tmp/
    Deleted/renamed all files starting with SAPI*. These files were remnants of the failed run on AAS, and new ones would be generated for the PAS-based execution in below steps

Manually Trigger tp Import

  • Executed the tp command manually on PAS in dialog mode:
    tp pf=/usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/var/TOOLIMPI.TPP put <SID>
    This command performed the transport import for TOOLIMP_I runs in dialog, wait for the command to complete successfully, it has taken 1:15 hour in our case.
    Meanwhile, new log files were generated under the tmp directory.

Sync Buffer File from PAS to AAS

  • Once the manual import finished, the buffer file in SUM directory of AAS was replaced with buffer file in the SUM directory of PAS:
    Buffer file location: /usr/sap/<SID>/SUM/abap/buffer/<SID>
    Copied this updated buffer file back to the SUM directory in AAS from SUM directory in PAS to ensure consistency.

Resume SUM on the AAS

  • Return to the SUM URL.
  • Selected â€œRepeat Phaseâ€ (not â€œStart from Beginningâ€).

SUM Moves On to next phase

  • SUM recognized from the updated buffer file that the TOOLIMP_I phase had already completed successfully and proceeded to next phase.

Result:

  • The long runtime in PREP_IMPORT/TOOLIMP_I during my DoDMO-based S/4HANA conversion was a valuable lesson in how even â€œpreparationâ€ phases can turn into critical bottlenecks. By carefully analyzing SUM behavior, ensuring environment consistency, and using controlled manual intervention, I was able to resolve an issue that had stalled for more than 30 hours and guide SUM back on track. This experience reinforced the importance of understanding SUMâ€™s internal processes, maintaining flexibility in troubleshooting, and always preparing for unexpected challenges during complex system conversions.

Thanks & Regards
Abhinav Mitra
SAP Technology Consultant

entry.title: Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4
entry.content:
Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Extensibility

I am pleased to announce the availability of the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4. In this blog post, I would like to provide a quick overview and highlight the changes in this newest release.

For a quick introduction to the methodology, please take a look here: SAP Application Extension Methodology.

This blog post is part of the series SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators.

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is a practical framework tailored to anyone using the SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP acts as the technological backbone for building, integrating, extending, and innovating with SAP solutions. Whether you're an enterprise architect, software developer, or administrator, SAP BTP offers significant opportunities for productivity and development.

 

Whatâ€™s New for SAP Application Extension Methodology

With the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4, we have made some changes to the Extension Technology Mapping. We now include the Clean Core Level concept directly in the Mapping, allowing you to easily follow the latest guidance. Next to each Technical Extension Building Block, you can find the corresponding Clean Core Level (A-D).

SAP Application Extension Methodology - Extension Technology Mapping with Clean Core Levels

Please be aware that the single source of truth for the Clean Core Levels is the official SAP Note 3578329. 

If you are still using an older version of the Technology Mapping, I highly recommend checking out our new version and to learn about the latest innovations and technologies on SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform.

 

Clean Core Level Concept in a Nutshell

Clean Core Levels Overview

TL;DR

  • Always develop your extension with the highest clean core level.
  • Leverage released APIs and best practice classic APIs of Level A and B to be clean core compliant.
  • Avoid not recommended SAP objects of Level D as they are not clean core compliant.

Level A

Level A is considered clean core and your strategic direction. You develop extension with SAP Build either on-stack on SAP S/4HANA and/or Side-by-Side on SAP BTP. Usually, you use a combination of both. You will use ABAP Cloud, CAP and our low-code/no-code tools in SAP Build. You can find the released APIs and extensions points on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Level B

Level B is considered clean core. You use upgrade stable classic APIs, which you can find in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = classic API.

Level C

Level C is considered conditionally clean. Use the internal SAP objects only if needed. There is no guarantee on long-term stability. Apply the changelog for SAP objects to mitigate upgrade risks.

Level D

Level D is considered NOT clean core. Those objects are unfit for customer use. You can find them in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = noAPI.

 

Next Steps:

Learn more about the SAP Application Extension Methodology on the SAP Help Portal.

Learn more about the SAP BTP Guidance Framework on the SAP Discovery Center and look out for the continuation of the blog post series. The next one will be about Data&Analytics.

Learn more about Clean Core by reading our detailed whitepaper, or tune into our latest Unlocking SAP BTP podcast episode focusing on clean core.

Feel free to like, comment and ask your questions!

Talk to you soon,
Marco

Product Manager SAP Business Technology Platform

entry.title: Selection of optimal scenario for Selective Data Transition to SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
This article is part of a series exploring SAP's Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE). In a previous blog, we provided an overview and the main value drivers of the SDT transition approach. In this article, we will discuss the optimal selection of an SDT scenario. Upcoming instalments will delve into methodology, tools, and more to clarify SDTE and showcase its benefits.

 

Transformation requirements

Enterprises operating on SAP ERP and considering a transition to SAP S/4HANA may have varying starting points and needs. Some may see the transition as a move to the next generation of software with minimal changes in system functionality and data. Others may use the SAP S/4HANA transition to revamp their system's foundation to better support current and future business needs, eliminating obsolete data and developments while introducing new features and innovations. Transformation requirements often depend on:

  • How long ago and how optimally the SAP ERP systems were implemented, and how significantly business models, structures, and processes have changed since then.
  • How prepared the current systems are to support business strategy, growth, and innovations.
  • The roadmap chosen by the enterprise for transformation, including investments planned before, during, and after the transition to SAP S/4HANA.

Selective Data Transition provides the flexibility to incorporate desired changes within the scope of the SAP S/4HANA transition project, encompassing multiple transition scenarios rather than one. Different scenarios may be optimal for different enterprises based on transformation and data migration requirements.

In the following sections, we will explore these scenarios and discuss how to select the most suitable one for your specific requirements. We'll begin with an overview of options for creating the target system and then examine various data migration scenarios.

Target system creation

Every SDT project begins with the decision on how the target SAP S/4HANA system will be created. The target system, also known as the "golden shell" or "golden template," is a system created at the start of the SDT project. It serves as the foundation for all systems within the SAP S/4HANA project and maintenance landscapes, including the future productive system.

Option 1. Shell conversion

The first option, "shell conversion," is suitable if most of your current SAP ERP assets (configured solutions, developments, data) need to be preserved and transitioned to SAP S/4HANA.

  1. Using a client copy or specific tools, create an empty copy of SAP ECC with all customizing and repository (code) but without any application data. This system is called the "SAP ECC shell."
  2. Perform required housekeeping activities in the empty SAP ECC shell system, such as removing unnecessary company codes. Unicode conversion or upgrades may be completed to meet system conversion prerequisites if required.
  3. Execute all activities necessary to prepare this system for conversion to SAP S/4HANA (data preparation is not required since there is no data in the system).
  4. Convert the prepared SAP ECC shell to SAP S/4HANA using a standard conversion toolset and complete SPAU, SPDD and post-conversion activities. This system becomes the "golden shell" of SAP S/4HANAâ€”a template for all future SAP S/4HANA systems, created as copies of the golden shell.
  5. Implement custom code adjustments and customizing changes required for simplification items or additional business requirements in the development system (a copy of the golden shell).
  6. Necessary data can be migrated to the copy of the configured system. More details on data migration scenarios described below.

Option 2. Mix and Match

The second option is suitable when most processes require modifications, and it becomes necessary to substantially reimplement the system. This approach supports these changes while retaining certain investments, such as configured solutions, developments, and data, for the transition to SAP S/4HANA.

In this scenario, a new SAP S/4HANA system is deployed, with standard content activated as necessary. Unlike a greenfield implementation, the target system will be enhanced by transferring selected elements from SAP ECC or an intermediate ECC system. This enhancement is supported by specialized tools.

The most common scenarios are illustrated in the image above.

Option 3. Special case â€“ Systems Consolidation

When it is necessary to consolidate multiple SAP ECC systems into a single instance of SAP S/4HANA, and there are significant similarities among the ECC systems, variations of options 1 and 2 can be utilized to create the target system, depending on specific requirements. A typical scenario is as follows:

  1. Select one of the consolidated systems as the main target.
  2. Create an SAP ECC shell from this system.
  3. Compare customization and repository of this SAP ECC shell with all the SAP ECC systems that will be consolidated manually or using specific tools, highlighting any identified differences.
  4. Analyze the differences and document how to resolve conflicts, collecting mappings between settings in the source and target systems to be used in the later data migration.
  5. Consolidate customizing and repositories in the SAP ECC shell system manually or using special tools based on documented decisions.
  6. Prepare the consolidated SAP ECC shell for conversion to SAP S/4HANA and convert it into the golden shell of SAP S/4HANA.

Once the target system is ready, an SAP S/4HANA development system is usually created as a copy to perform necessary application-specific customizing and custom-code adjustments. Completion of these prepares the system for data migration and testing.

SDT Scenarios Overview

SDT scenarios described below represent best practices commonly used in SDTE community projects. Even if the terms or names may slightly vary among different partners, the meaning and practices remain consistent within the community. After creating the target SAP S/4HANA system, finding an optimal path for data migration addressing specific requirements is essential.

Scenario 1. Regular SDT â€“ table-based data migration and transformation

In this scenario, selected SAP ERP system data is migrated to SAP S/4HANA at the database table level using specialized tools. Specific considerations include:

  • Target system creation is preferably achieved via the shell conversion.
  • Table-based migration enables fast data transfer, resulting in short downtime since migration occurs at the database level. Unlike posting based technology (e.g. Migration Cockpit) no application-level logic is executed for the data migration, thus careful data validation and process testing is crucial post-migration.
  • Required transformation routines are executed in the SAP S/4HANA target system post or during migration to transform the data into the SAP S/4HANA data model.
  • Historical transactional data can be migrated using this approach, with filters applicable based on organizational units (e.g., data for selected company codes) or time slices (e.g., the last three years of data), or individual filters for data migration objects. Data cleansing and preparation of the migrated data in source systems may be needed (for example consistency of finance historical data).
  • Go-live can be scheduled at any time during the fiscal year, as all necessary data for finance reporting is usually migrated, avoiding data slicing between systems.
  • Downtime for source and target systems is usually required during the table-based migration.
  • Transformations can be applied to migrated data based on mappings, renaming, or renumbering logic. Some S/4HANA transformation pre-projects (e.g., Business Partners creation) may be embedded in the SDT migration process. However, limitations may exist on integrating many "on-the-fly" transformations simultaneously on the same data set at the same time.

Scenario 2. Lean SDT â€“ selective table-based data migration without transformation requirements

Lean Selective Data Transition is the standard solution provided by SAP for identifying and transferring relevant data during migration from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA using the SAP Business Transformation Center. Technically, Lean SDT resembles Option 1: shell creation is necessary, and all data migrates at the table level with organizational unit or time slice filters. However, Lean SDT offers no data transformations and no systems consolidation, whereas regular SDT provides more flexibility and broader transformation possibilities.

Scenario 3. Hybrid SDT â€“ combination of table-based data migration & postings

In this scenario, selected SAP ERP data for specific areas (e.g., master data, logistics, plant maintenance) migrated to SAP S/4HANA at the database table level using special tools, while postings (using tools like SAP Migration Cockpit or specific consulting tools) are used for other data objects (e.g., finance open items, balances, and inventory stocks). Specific considerations include:

  • Postings trigger application-level validations of migrated data, increasing confidence in data quality within the target system. However, postings may take longer than table-based migration and require higher data cleansing standards.
  • Historical transactional data cannot be migrated using standard posting methodologies. Only current open orders, open items, balances, and stocks can be transferred to the target instance.
  • Go-live is advisable at the beginning of the fiscal year, as data needed for finance reporting may be sliced between systems otherwise, impacting migration scope and efforts (P&L, assets).
  • Postings occur through data re-creation using API (BAPI) in the target system considering local system settings. Therefore, postings provide a simplified option to redesign functional and structural changes, at the expense of loss of historical data.

SDT Scenario Selection

Selecting an optimal SDT scenario is primarily driven by transformation and data migration requirements and includes decisions on the target system creation option and data migration approach.

Decision on a target system creation option depends on the changes needed in the system functionality and structures. This influences the scope of the transformation. The shell creation approach predominantly reuses current SAP ERP system customizing and repository, indicating that migrated data mostly fits the new system as it is in the source. The Mix and Match approach suggests that primarily spot solutions will remain unchanged in the future SAP S/4HANA compared to the current SAP ERP, starting from a new fresh system reducing the data migration scope/volume and increasing complexity of transformation.

To select an optimal data migration strategy, it is essential to identify, at least at a high level, the mandatory and desired functional and structural changes (transformations) that will occur in the new SAP S/4HANA system compared to the existing SAP ERP. This question is closely related to data migration scope. Migrating historical transactional data means all required transformations must occur within this data, which can be complex and challenging for certain transformations and data objects.

Project risks, efforts, and duration can be managed with a balanced approach between functional transformations and data migration scope. If functional transformations are driven by changes in business models and processes, they cannot usually be sacrificed and must be executed during the SAP S/4HANA transition. In such cases, data migration scope can be limited to postings of master data and open items to new structures in heavily transformed areas.

Other factors influencing scenario selection include planned go-live date (beginning of fiscal year or not), systems consolidation needs, data volumes, downtime requirements, and potential for transformational pre- or post-projects.

To summarize, selecting the optimal SDT scenario requires knowledge of:

  • Mandatory and desired functional and structural changes (transformations) in the new SAP S/4HANA system compared to the existing SAP ERP.
  • Required data migration scope in different areas (Finance, Logistics/Operation, HR).
  • Downtime, go-live date, system consolidation, and other special requirements.

These topics must be discussed all together since they influence each other. A balanced approach might be required to select the most optimal SDT scenario that will provide the safest, easiest, and fastest pathway to SAP S/4HANA target architecture.

Success Stories

German manufacturer in the food sector: Selective Data Transition of the last 2 years

The customer moved document date from the last two years from his old ECC into S/4HANA environment.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Shell creation: Technical preparation of the future S/4HANA target system
  • Filtered selection: Time slice level to just bring the necessary organizational structures with current and last two fiscal year into the new environment
  • SDT transformation approach: CO area restructuring (mainly merging, but also some splits), chart of accounts harmonization, introduction of New GL and New Asset Accounting, introduction of group currency

Energy Industry (Germany): Selective Data Transition with filtered migration

The customer moved from his 20-year-old SAP ECC into a new SAP S/4HANA environment including a separation of energy industry specific data (SAP IS-U) from core ERP logistic and finance data.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Shell creation: Technical preparation of the future S/4HANA target system
  • Filtered selection: Filter on organizational and time slice level to just bring the necessary organizational structures with current and last fiscal year into the new environment
  • SDT transformation approach: Regular SDT including transformations like a controlling area split and bringing the data into the S/4HANA data model

Call to Action

Youâ€™ve seen that selecting an optimal SDT scenario is primarily driven by transformation and data migration scope requirements and includes decisions on the target system creation option and data migration approach.

In the next episode, we will discuss the advantages of systems consolidation and SDT usage for that purpose.

In the meantime:

  1. Explore Webinars & Resources
    Discover more about SDTE via official SAP Support Portal webinars or community sessions that dive deeper into the specifics.
  2. Contact the SDTE Community
    Reach out to the expert group of SAP and its partners for an assessment of your current landscape. They can help identify how selective data transition can best fit your needs.
  3. Start Your Transformation
    Donâ€™t wait until maintenance windows close or all experts are not available anymore. A well-planned selective data migration can future-proof your IT environment and jump-start your intelligent enterprise journey.

Take the next step by visiting
SDTE Engagement Overview
to connect with the SDTE community and chart out your custom path to SAP S/4HANA success.
