entry.title: Use of Settlement Material in SAP S/4HANA Condition Contract
entry.content:
Overview

Entering a settlement material in a condition contract is optional. However, in scenarios such as those involving product groups, where multiple materials are assigned to a specific product group, it is more efficient to perform settlement using a â€œsettlement materialâ€ rather than settling each individual material. In such cases, specifying a settlement material in the condition contract becomes necessary.

Key Process Consideration

The material will always be transferred from source document to settlement document if you are using a profile of business volume with a split criteria MATNR (material number). When creating a condition contract, you can enter a settlement material that represents a group of products. Then, when you run the final settlement, system uses this single reference instead of listing every product.

If you want system to use the settlement material instead of the actual product from the original document, you must do following additional settings:

# In split criteria for settlement of profile for BV determination change usage control to â€œ1: Is used â€“ Unless Deactivated via process variantâ€

 

# Create a new process variant & define a field MATNR in the split criteria and select â€œ1: Do not use as a split criterionâ€ in usage as split criteriaâ€.

Then, create the condition contract and enter the settlement material. define which product group it applies to in business volume selection criteria. Then run the settlement using transactions like WB2R_SC or WB2R_SV. The system will show the settlement material in the final document.

To get the best results make sure your product groups are well set up. Test your setup in a sandbox system to avoid issues. Use clear names for settlement materials so reports are easy to understand. Also, make sure your setup matches how your business tracks volumes and sales.

Using settlement material also helps simplify accounting because you donâ€™t need a separate rule for each product. It makes reporting easier since you can track performance using one reference. You can even automate the selection of settlement materials to save time. And if business handles thousands of products, this feature can really speed things up.

Conclusion

Settlement material is a powerful tool in SAP S/4HANA that can make contract and settlement management much easier. It helps you work faster, stay organized & get clearer insights. With the right setup and testing  it can be a big help for both customer and vendor settlements.

Happy Learning!

entry.title: Dashboard and Business AI Insights for SAP License Simulation and Analysis
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP has introduced the SAM4U solution, an excellent tool to gather data from SAP backend systems for the consolidation and analysis of users, engines, and HANA EE license consumption.

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, available on SAP Store, provides extended analytics and simulation capabilities to view SAM4U data from new angles. It empowers customers moving to S/4HANA, S/4HANA Private Cloud, or already working under an SAP RISE contract to run different â€œwhat ifâ€ scenarios based on data extracted from their SAP system, helping them find the best approach to optimize SAP license consumption.

What Was Missing?

While SAM4U provides valuable transparency, customers often asked:

  • How do I see the potential savings?

  • How do I define a strategy for optimization?

  • Where exactly should I focus my cleanup efforts?

License optimization typically falls into three categories:

  • Fast optimization: achieved quickly with user data cleanup in SAP backend

  • Obtainable optimization: achievable in reasonable time with cleanup and role/profile tuning

  • Maximal optimization: the long-term goal, achieved when roles and authorizations are precisely aligned with actual usage

What was missing was clarity and insights to navigate these paths effectively.

How it is solved

The new release of the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings two major updates:

  • Clarity through an extremely informative dashboard

  • Business AI insights powered by the Skybuffer AI platform, an SAP Business AI certified solution from SAP Store

The dashboard

 Pic. 1 The Dashboard

One of the central KPIs is License Optimization Potential, which shows the estimated current contract costs compared to optimized contract costs. The KPI highlights savings that can be achieved either through the fast users cleanup approach or the obtainable approach of cleaning up users and optimizing roles with the highest optimization potential.

 Pic. 2 License Optimization Potential

There are many other useful insights. For example, it shows how many authorization objects are not used at all. This is a target for maximal optimization and one reason it is not so easily obtainable. The lower the number, the better the authorizations are aligned with active usage.

 Pic. 3 Excess Authorization

The evaluation of maximal optimization is also visualized by the FUE Gap KPI:

 Pic. 4 FUE Gap - Authorization vs Active Usage

There is also a very helpful hint about SAP_ALL and SAP_NEW profiles still in use in production:

 Pic. 5 Users with Sensitive Authorization Profiles

The total number of roles and profiles that can be optimized and the savings this brings are also clearly summarized:

 Pic. 6 Excess Roles

The insights

Business AI insights in the dashboard bring extra clarity and understanding. For example, they show the fast optimization saving potential and provide clear explanations and strategies on how to reach it:

Pic. 7 Business AI Insights

AI recommendations are also available for obtainable or maximal optimization:

 Pic. 8 Max and Obtainable Optimization

Effectively, this functions as a personal SAP License Analysis and Optimization consultant, virtualized and trained to understand the organizationâ€™s own data.

The AI Assistant is always there, and expanding its knowledge base is straightforward through the Skybuffer AI platform. For example, it can present the top 10 roles for optimization or provide additional information related to SAP licensing:

 Pic. 9 Top 10 Roles for Optimization

Of course, all the well-established simulation and analysis tools of the Accelerator remain available. With the new release, they work even better, helping to test and simulate the AI Assistantâ€™s recommendations.

Conclusion

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption now provides one of the most powerful toolsets on the market to analyze and optimize SAP users and engines licenses independently. It helps avoid the significant costs of SAP license optimization consulting and delivers deep insights into user and engine data. This comes without the need for a complex SAM4U installation and without spending time and money on consulting services that quickly become outdated.

What to do next?

Running SAP under a RISE contract? Use the dashboard and Business AI insights at least once per month to avoid FUE consumption increases and surprises. Train your team with the solution and the organization will not face unpredictable growth of SAP license consumption. entry.title: Protect Your SAP S/4HANA from Critical Code Injection Vulnerability [CVE-2025-42957]
entry.content:
Protect Your SAP S/4HANA from Critical Code Injection Vulnerability [CVE-2025-42957] with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection and SAP Enterprise Threat Detection, cloud edition.

A critical ABAP code injection vulnerability (CVE-2025-42957) has been discovered in SAP S/4HANA (Private Cloud or On-Premise), exposing SAP systems to potential exploits. This vulnerability allows attackers with user privileges to inject arbitrary ABAP code, bypassing essential authorization checks and putting the entire system at risk of compromise.

Key Details:

  • Vulnerability ID: CVE-2025-42957

  • CVSS v3.0 Base Score: 9.9 / 10

  • Impacted Components: S4CORE 102 - 108

Understanding the Threat:

This flaw operates as a backdoor, allowing unauthorized access to SAP systems and jeopardizing confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Without immediate mitigation, your SAP S/4HANA system could be severely compromised.

Monitoring with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection (SAP ETD):

SAP Enterprise Threat Detection plays a crucial role in identifying and mitigating such vulnerabilities. By adding the function module /SLOAE/DEPLOY to the value list ABAP Blocklisted Function Modules, SAP Enterprise Threat Detection can monitor and flag potential exploitation of this vulnerability.

Additionally, SAP Enterprise Threat Detection can be configured to track the frequency and context of calls to this critical function module. In a recent review of a production system landscape containing 34bn log events it was observed that this function module was not called at all over the last several months, validating its inclusion in threat detection parameters avoiding fals positives.

Steps to Secure Your SAP System:

  1. Patch Installation: Apply the correction instructions or support packages referenced by SAP Note 3627998 to eliminate code injection risks today!

  2. SAP Enterprise Threat Detection Monitoring: Add /SLOAE/DEPLOY to ABAP Blocklisted Function Modules in SAP Enterprise Threat Detection to monitor attempts to exploit this vulnerability.

  3. System Audits: Regularly audit your system for unauthorized access, privileged access, fraudulat behaviour and other signs of exploitation with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection.

For further information and the latest updates, refer to the SAP Security Note 3627998.

SAP Enterprise Threat Detection information: sap.com

Kind regards,

Arndt

Stay vigilant and ensure your SAP systems are protected from evolving threats.

entry.title: Aggregator component in SAP Cloud Integration - Correlation function
entry.content:
The Aggregator component is a very powerful and versatile component, which can be used for many different things. Today we will focus on the Correlation feature.

Working with data file interfaces, it is common that data arrives in a raw and flat format, often containing multiple records that belong logically together. In SAP Cloud Integration (CPI), the Aggregator step helps us collect and group these messages so that they can be processed as a single unit.

In this blog post, we will look at scenario where we receive General Ledger (GL) records that must be paired into Credit and Debit entries, based on a common GL ID. Weâ€™ll use the Correlation function of the Aggregator to achieve this grouping. The Aggregator may be overlooked as the first go-to option and we may be thinking about Groovy scripts or XSLT transformation, but Aggregator is the smoothest way to do this.

The Input Data

Our source system delivers data in a flat, delimited structure:

US01|01 01 180000039|US01|0011040120|0011040120||01012025|01012025|01012025|D|USD|100.00|USD|100.00|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||
US01|01 01 180000039|US01|0011040100|0011040100||01012025|01012025|01012025|C|USD|100.00|USD|100.00|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||
US01|02 01 180000080|US01|0011040120|0011040120||02012025|02012025|02012025|D|USD|150.00|USD|150.00|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||
US01|02 01 180000080|US01|0011040100|0011040100||02012025|02012025|02012025|C|USD|150.00|USD|150.00|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

These are four GL records, which actually form two logical pairs:

  • Debit & Credit for GL ID 01 01 180000039
  • Debit & Credit for GL ID 02 01 180000080

The field at position 2 is the GL Id and field at position 10 indicates whether it is Debit (D) or Credit (C).

Converting Flat Data to XML

Since the Aggregator works with XML, our first task is to transform the flat file into XML. This is done using CSV to XML Converter component.

Here we have to provide:

  • XSD schema â€“ to define the structure of the incoming message.

  

  • Path to target element - this is the path in xsd where the GL record is actually stored
  • Field separator - a pipe in our case

After the message passes this step, we get one XML with four records like this.
 

Now we have to split this single XML into separate messages using Splitter to be able to use the Aggregator component, as it works with individual XMLs and performs the aggregation / correlation on them. We are splitting again on the /root/item xpath.
You can see the sequence on the screenshot above: Converter -> Splitter -> Aggregator.

Grouping with the Aggregator

Now comes the interesting part: Aggregator with Correlation.
In the Aggregator step, we configure the Correlation Expression to use the GL_Id field.

This ensures that all records sharing the same GL_Id are collected into a single group. Once the group is complete (for example, after receiving both Debit and Credit), the Aggregator releases the combined message.

As a result, instead of four separate records, we get two XML documents grouped on GL_Id value. In the terms of SAP, we got a paired GL posting record with Debit and Credit side.

Mapping to S/4HANA

Of course, SAP S/4HANA expects different field names and a slightly different XML structure for posting GL documents.
Here we typically use an XSLT mapping or a Message Mapping step to transform the aggregatorâ€™s output into the required S/4HANA format.
These steps are highly dependent on the target API (e.g. Journal Entry API), but conceptually itâ€™s just restructuring fields.

End-to-End Flow

Summarizing the integration steps:

  1. Receive Flat File (pipe-delimited records).
  2. Convert to XML using XSD + converter.
  3. Split per individual records
  4. Aggregate Records by GL_Id with Correlation.
  5. Transform to S/4HANA Format via XSLT mapping.
  6. Send to S/4HANA using the standard OData/HTTPS adapter.

The Correlation feature of the Aggregator in SAP CPI is very helpful. It allows us to logically group related recordsâ€”even if they arrive as separate messagesâ€”so that downstream systems like S/4HANA receive them as consistent and balanced documents.
